markdownRemark.html:
prompt examples

  • detail outlined books, articles, etcâ€¦

    • expand in much more details with bold high-light quotes/phrases in depth and more examples for the above sections ""
    • second pass:
      • expand in much more details, with bold high-light quotes/phrases, in depth and more examples for "" please

  • community research

you're an expert in realestate investing, give me detailed outline on the Hotchkiss neighborhood in Calgary with the following questions:
- what are nearby amenities, attractions?
- when was the houses were commonly built?
- what are the common building type?
- what are the zoning regulations? does zoning regulations allows more units per lot?
- what is the population? what is the population growth?
- what is the average income in the area?
- what is the crime rate?
- what are the rentals supply/demand in the communities?
- what are the average rents?
- is it A, B, C, D neighborhood?
- what are the long-term potential appreciation compared to current returns and cashflow?
- what is average house prices?
- what real estate investment strategies could work for this neighborhood?

  • complete Dept Snapshot

    • Hereâ€™s all my debt: [type, balance, interest rate]. Organize by urgency, interest, and balance to create a clear payoff roadmap.
    • Hereâ€™s my monthly income and all expenses: [list]. Identify at least 3 areas to cut or optimize without lowering quality of life
    • Based on the debt list, create a monthly payment plan using snowball or avalanche method, including exact amounts and milestones.
    • Create a visual debt reduction tracker I can fill weekly. Include milestones, reward checkpoints, and motivational prompts for consistent progress.
    • Build a monthly checklist to update debts, review progress, adjust payments, and reallocate extra funds toward faster debt payoff.

  • streaming setup

    • Act as a media organizer. Create a full system where I can access free, legal movie libraries online
    • Find the top 10 open-source platforms that stream free films & series â€” categorize them by quality.
    • Design a step-by-step guide to connect these platforms into one hub for easy access.
    • Suggest browser extensions or apps to centralize all free movie sources.
    • Make my setup ad-free using only safe & legal methods.
    • Generate a daily list of trending free movies I can watch tonight.
    • Act as a personal movie concierge â€” recommend titles based on my past viewing taste.

  • consolidate all of provided information

    • Please consolidate all the information you have provided in our discussion "" into one structured text. Eliminate redundancy and organize it logically by topic

  • TDD development

We are doing test driven development. For each task, do the following:

  1. Add a test to the test file specified by the user.
  2. Run the tests and ensure it fails. If it doesnâ€™t stop.
  3. Add the implementation to the implementation file specified by the user.
  4. Run the tests and ensure it passes. If it doesnâ€™t attempt to fix it by changing only the implementation.
  5. Commit it, starting the commit message with ğŸ¤– do denote the commit was done by you.
  6. Stop and wait for the next task.

If the task involves refactoring, take small steps figure out a sequence of small moves that minimize the amount of time the code is broken. Treat each small step as a task, run the tests, and commit after each one.

If the user doesnâ€™t specify test and implementation files, stop and ask the user before continuing. DO NOT USE TOOLS TO TRY TO FIND THE FILES.

Quotes

References

  • https://www.promptingguide.ai/
  • https://www.amazon.ca/Art-Prompt-Engineering-ChatGPT-Plugins-ebook/dp/B0BSN3PTX8
  • https://www.amazon.ca/Prompt-Engineering-LLMs-Model-Based-Applications/dp/1098156153/

Got it. Iâ€™ll update and expand the original outline of Boundaries: When to Say Yes, How to Say No by integrating the revised / updated audio transcript you uploaded.

What follows is not a summary, but a deep, structured, emotionally-intelligent outline that reflects:

  • the core framework of the original book
  • new emphases, clarifications, and pastoral nuance from the updated audio
  • clearer psychological mechanisms, motives, and failure modes
  • practical boundary diagnostics you can actually apply in work, family, marriage, church, and parenting

Iâ€™ll flag whatâ€™s new or expanded relative to the classic edition as we go.

ğŸ“˜ UPDATED MASTER OUTLINE â€” Boundaries (Revised & Expanded Audio Edition)

PART I â€” WHAT BOUNDARIES ARE (AND WHY LIFE BREAKS WITHOUT THEM)

1. A Day in a Boundaryless Life (Sherryâ€™s Story)

Core Insight:

â€œTrying harder, being nicer, and loving more do not fix boundary problems.â€

Updated emphasis from audio:

  • Boundarylessness produces:

    • chronic resentment
    • emotional exhaustion
    • spiritual confusion
    • relational power imbalances

  • Sherryâ€™s problem is not lack of love, but:

    • confusion about ownership
    • taking responsibility for what God never assigned to her

  • Boundary failure always spreads:

    • marriage
    • children (discipline issues, withdrawal)
    • work (overfunctioning)
    • church (guilt-driven service)

Key diagnostic question introduced implicitly:

â€œWhose problem am I solving right now?â€

2. What Is a Boundary?

Definition refined:

A boundary defines what is me and what is not me, and therefore what I am responsible for.

Expanded clarity:

  • Boundaries are not walls â†’ they are fences with gates

  • They exist to:

    • protect what is good
    • expose what is broken
    • preserve the soul (Proverbs 4:23)

Core principle reinforced:

â€œIf I donâ€™t define my property line, someone else will.â€

3. Responsibility Clarified (Galatians 6 Deep Dive)

Important refinement (often missed):

Verse Meaning
Gal 6:2 Help carry boulders (crises, trauma)
Gal 6:5 Carry your own knapsack (daily responsibilities)

Updated warning from audio:

  • Confusing these two creates:

    • rescuers
    • perpetual victims
    • entitled adults

  • Parents, spouses, managers, churches often steal problems from others, preventing maturity

PART II â€” WHAT BOUNDARIES LOOK LIKE IN REAL LIFE

4. Common Boundary Markers (Expanded)

Classic markers (retained):

  • Skin
  • Words (â€œyesâ€ / â€œnoâ€)
  • Truth
  • Distance
  • Time
  • Consequences
  • Supportive relationships

Audio expansion:

  • Anger as an early-warning system
  • Consequences as moral clarity, not punishment
  • Distance is sometimes the only language abusers understand

PART III â€” THE LAWS OF BOUNDARIES (SIGNIFICANTLY EXPANDED)

Law 1â€“3 (unchanged structurally)

  • Law of Sowing & Reaping
  • Law of Responsibility
  • Law of Power

Law 4 â€” The Law of Respect (Expanded)

Key addition:

â€œYou cannot demand respect for your boundaries while judging the boundaries of others.â€

New insight from audio:

  • Judging othersâ€™ boundaries creates a fear loop:

    • â€œTheyâ€™ll judge me tooâ€
    • â†’ compliance
    • â†’ resentment
    • â†’ love turns sour

Freedom principle:

â€œFreedom begets freedom.â€

Respecting othersâ€™ â€œnoâ€ is the price of owning your own.

Law 5 â€” The Law of Motivation (Major Expansion)

Core upgrade:

Freedom first. Service second.

False motives for saying â€œyesâ€ (expanded list):

  1. Fear of losing love
  2. Fear of anger
  3. Fear of loneliness
  4. Confusing love with compliance
  5. Guilt
  6. Payback (emotional debt)
  7. Approval addiction
  8. Over-identification with othersâ€™ pain

Critical diagnostic:

â€œIf your giving produces depression instead of joy, it is not love.â€

This is one of the most psychologically important expansions in the revised audio.

Law 6 â€” The Law of Evaluation (Clarified with Key Distinction)

Major teaching refinement:

Hurt â‰  Harm

  • Boundaries often hurt
  • But they heal in the long run
  • Avoiding hurt creates destruction

New metaphor used:

  • Dentist drilling â†’ hurts but heals
  • Sugar â†’ feels good but harms

Boundary maturity =

  • empathizing with pain
  • without surrendering responsibility

Law 7 â€” The Law of Proactivity (Heavily Expanded)

Critical developmental insight:

Stage Description
Reactive Necessary after abuse
Proactive Required for maturity

New warning:

â€œA reactive stage is a stage â€” not an identity.â€

Power shift:

  • Reactive people are known by what they oppose
  • Proactive people are known by what they love and build

Spiritual adulthood defined:

Not demanding power, but restraining it

Law 8 â€” The Law of Envy (Expanded Psychological Depth)

New framing:

â€œEnvy is a signal that you are neglecting your own responsibility.â€

Boundary failure creates envy because:

  • energy is spent watching others
  • instead of building your own life

Updated corrective move:

  • Replace comparison with self-examination

  • Ask:

    • What am I avoiding?
    • What risk am I unwilling to take?

Law 9 â€” The Law of Activity (Strong Expansion)

New central warning:

â€œPassivity is an ally of evil.â€

Refined theology:

  • God covers failure
  • God does not enable passivity

Powerful metaphor added:

  • Baby bird must peck out of the egg
  • Rescue kills growth

Law 10 â€” The Law of Exposure (Major Emphasis)

Key principle:

â€œUnexpressed boundaries donâ€™t disappear â€” they leak out destructively.â€

New clinical patterns highlighted:

  • Silent compliance â†’ sudden divorce
  • Years of giving â†’ explosive rage
  • Hidden resentment â†’ manipulation

Healing principle reinforced:

â€œHealing only happens in the light.â€

PART IV â€” COMMON BOUNDARY MYTHS (SIGNIFICANTLY DEEPENED)

Myth 1: â€œBoundaries Are Selfishâ€

Reframed as:

  • Selfishness = fixation on wants
  • Boundaries = stewardship of Godâ€™s investment

Myth 2: â€œBoundaries Are Disobedientâ€

Key addition:

â€œAn internal no cancels an external yes.â€

God values cheerful, voluntary obedience, not fear-driven compliance.

Myth 3: â€œIf I Set Boundaries, Iâ€™ll Be Abandonedâ€

New relational litmus test:

â€œPeople who only love your yes do not love you.â€

Boundaries reveal relationship quality â€” they donâ€™t destroy it.

Myth 4: â€œBoundaries Hurt Othersâ€

Clarification:

  • Boundaries are defensive, not offensive
  • Adults are responsible for finding alternate support

Myth 5: â€œBoundaries Mean Iâ€™m Angryâ€

Major emotional intelligence upgrade:

  • Anger is a boundary alarm
  • Old anger surfaces when new boundaries appear
  • Mature boundaries reduce anger over time

â€œDonâ€™t get mad. Set a limit.â€

Myth 6: â€œOthersâ€™ Boundaries Injure Meâ€

New diagnostic clarity: Inability to accept othersâ€™ boundaries often indicates:

  • childhood boundary injury
  • projection
  • emotional over-dependence
  • refusal to take responsibility

FINAL SYNTHESIS â€” WHAT THE REVISED EDITION MAKES CLEARER

The updated audio sharpens this truth:

Boundaries are not about control. They are about love, responsibility, and maturity.

They:

  • protect the soul
  • expose sin and dysfunction
  • enable joy instead of resentment
  • turn victims into agents
  • transform relationships instead of preserving illusions

If you want, next we can:

  • ğŸ” map your own life against the Laws of Boundaries
  • ğŸ§  analyze where guilt, fear, or anger are blocking you
  • ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘§â€ğŸ‘¦ apply this specifically to parenting, work, or marriage
  • ğŸ‡»ğŸ‡³ translate this into a Vietnamese deep-study outline

Just tell me where you want to go next.
